title: How to Make Olive Bread

methods.name: Making Simple Olive- and Cheese-Topped Bread

steps.headline: Drain the olives.
steps.description: Strain the juices from both cans of olives. You can dump them into a strainer or simply use the lid to strain out most of the juice.

steps.headline: Grate the cheese.
steps.description: Use a cheese grater or food processor to grate the cheese. It can be fine or coarse.

steps.headline: Slice the bread.
steps.description: Slice the bread lengthwise, creating two long pieces. This step is similar to how you'd make garlic bread.

steps.headline: Chop the olives.
steps.description: Give them a rough chop with a knife. They don't need to be finely chopped.

steps.headline: Slice the green onions.
steps.description: Finely slice the onions, including the greens. First, wash the onions. Chop off the root ends. Peel off the outer layer if you feel like it's too dirty. Line up the onions, and use your knife to make slices, starting at the root end.

steps.headline: Add all the ingredients to a bowl.
steps.description: Mix the mayonnaise, onions, olives, cheese, and butter in a bowl.

steps.headline: Smooth over the bread.
steps.description: Using a large spoon or knife, cover the cut side of the bread in the mixture. It will be fairly thick.

steps.headline: Place the bread on a baking sheet.
steps.description: The olive mixture should be face-up.

steps.headline: Cook the bread.
steps.description: Bake the bread for 20 to 25 minutes at 325 °F (163 °C). The cheese should be melted and bubbly when it's done.

steps.headline: Cut into slices.
steps.description: Once the bread has cooled, slice it up and serve it. You should get about 6 slices per side.

steps.headline: Set the oven to preheat.
steps.description: Set the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C).

steps.headline: Cook the onion.
steps.description: Place a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Add the oil, and let it heat up. Throw in the onion, and cook until the onion is translucent. Take it off the heat.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients.
steps.description: In a bowl, mix the flour, baking soda, and salt.

steps.headline: Create a well in the flour.
steps.description: That is, use your hand to make a depression in the flour mound.

steps.headline: Mix the liquid in another bowl.
steps.description: Add the buttermilk, butter, and egg whites to another bowl. Mix them together.

steps.headline: Pour the liquid into the flour well.
steps.description: Stir it together to incorporate the flour and liquid. Don't overmix.

steps.headline: Add in the chopped pieces and spice.
steps.description: Stir in the onions, olives, and oregano. Fold them in gently.

steps.headline: Grease a pan.
steps.description: Spray an 8 inch (20.3 cm) by 4 inch loaf pan with cooking spray. Spoon the batter in the pan evenly. Wipe off any spilled batter.

steps.headline: Cook for 45 minutes.
steps.description: Test for doneness by inserting a toothpick. It should be clean when it comes out.

steps.headline: Set the pan on a wire rack.
steps.description: Let it sit for 10 minutes. Once it's cooled, take the bread out and place it on the wire rack to cool further.

methods.name: Creating French Bread with Olives and Thyme

steps.headline: Heat the milk, butter, and sugar.
steps.description: Place the milk in a saucepan. Heat over medium to medium-high heat until it simmers, then mix in the butter and sugar. Keeping stirring it. The butter needs to melt into the mixture.

steps.headline: Pour the liquid into another container.
steps.description: In a large bowl, add the milk. Pour in the water (at room temperature). Let it cool until it reaches about 95 °F (35 °C).

steps.headline: Stir in the yeast.
steps.description: When the mixture is lukewarm, mix in the yeast. If the liquid is too hot, it will kill the yeast. Warm liquid, on the other hand, encourages the yeast to flourish. Remember to pick the correct yeast for the time you are making it. If you are making the bread a day or two before you want to bake it, use the active dry yeast. If you plan to bake the bread the day you make it, use the quick-rising dry yeast.

steps.headline: Add flavor.
steps.description: Mix in the olives, thyme, and salt, followed by a cup of flour. Mix it until the flour disappears.

steps.headline: Add in the rest of the flour.
steps.description: Separating each cup, add in the flour cup by cup. Between additions, stir until the flour disappears. You can add more flour if the dough is too sticky. The dough should start pulling away from the sides of the bowl.

steps.headline: Add the oil to a bowl, smoothing it up the sides.
steps.description: Dump the dough into it to cover it in oil. Place the dough in the fridge if you are making it ahead. If not, leave it to rise in a warm area of the room. When it's ready, the dough will be doubled.

steps.headline: Heat the oven to 500 °F (260 °C).
steps.description: Let the oven preheat for 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Rub a baking sheet with olive oil.
steps.description: Using your hands or a spoon, thoroughly coat a sheet with olive oil. The olive oil helps create a crispy crust on the bottom.

steps.headline: Flour an area to work.
steps.description: Turn the dough out on the surface, making sure not to knead it. Cut it in half.

steps.headline: Create baguettes.
steps.description: They should be 15 inches (38.1 cm) long and a couple of inches wide. Place them on the sheet.

steps.headline: Let the dough rise again.
steps.description: In a warm area, leave the dough to rise for about 15 minutes (30 if using the dough from the refrigerator). Leave plastic wrap over it while it's rising.

steps.headline: Top with egg white.
steps.description: Using a pastry brush, coat the top of each loaf with egg white.

steps.headline: Humidify the oven.
steps.description: Water helps create a crusty loaf. Use a spray bottle to spray tap water into the oven, about 8 times.

steps.headline: Start with 10 minutes.
steps.description: Begin baking the bread at 500 °F (260 °C) for 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Lower the temperature to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.description: Finish baking the bread for 35 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove it to a cooling rack.
steps.description: Let it cool before serving.

text: Making Simple Olive- and Cheese-Topped Bread Drain the olives. Strain the juices from both cans of olives. You can dump them into a strainer or simply use the lid to strain out most of the juice. Grate the cheese. Use a cheese grater or food processor to grate the cheese. It can be fine or coarse. Slice the bread. Slice the bread lengthwise, creating two long pieces. This step is similar to how you'd make garlic bread. Chop the olives. Give them a rough chop with a knife. They don't need to be finely chopped. Slice the green onions. Finely slice the onions, including the greens. First, wash the onions. Chop off the root ends. Peel off the outer layer if you feel like it's too dirty. Line up the onions, and use your knife to make slices, starting at the root end. Add all the ingredients to a bowl. Mix the mayonnaise, onions, olives, cheese, and butter in a bowl. Smooth over the bread. Using a large spoon or knife, cover the cut side of the bread in the mixture. It will be fairly thick. Place the bread on a baking sheet. The olive mixture should be face-up. Cook the bread. Bake the bread for 20 to 25 minutes at 325 °F (163 °C). The cheese should be melted and bubbly when it's done. Cut into slices. Once the bread has cooled, slice it up and serve it. You should get about 6 slices per side. Preparing No-Yeast Olive Bread Set the oven to preheat. Set the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C). Cook the onion. Place a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Add the oil, and let it heat up. Throw in the onion, and cook until the onion is translucent. Take it off the heat. Mix the dry ingredients. In a bowl, mix the flour, baking soda, and salt. Create a well in the flour. That is, use your hand to make a depression in the flour mound. Mix the liquid in another bowl. Add the buttermilk, butter, and egg whites to another bowl. Mix them together. Pour the liquid into the flour well. Stir it together to incorporate the flour and liquid. Don't overmix. Add in the chopped pieces and spice. Stir in the onions, olives, and oregano. Fold them in gently. Grease a pan. Spray an 8 inch (20.3 cm) by 4 inch loaf pan with cooking spray. Spoon the batter in the pan evenly. Wipe off any spilled batter. Cook for 45 minutes. Test for doneness by inserting a toothpick. It should be clean when it comes out. Set the pan on a wire rack. Let it sit for 10 minutes. Once it's cooled, take the bread out and place it on the wire rack to cool further. Creating French Bread with Olives and Thyme Heat the milk, butter, and sugar. Place the milk in a saucepan. Heat over medium to medium-high heat until it simmers, then mix in the butter and sugar. Keeping stirring it. The butter needs to melt into the mixture. Pour the liquid into another container. In a large bowl, add the milk. Pour in the water (at room temperature). Let it cool until it reaches about 95 °F (35 °C). Stir in the yeast. When the mixture is lukewarm, mix in the yeast. If the liquid is too hot, it will kill the yeast. Warm liquid, on the other hand, encourages the yeast to flourish. Remember to pick the correct yeast for the time you are making it. If you are making the bread a day or two before you want to bake it, use the active dry yeast. If you plan to bake the bread the day you make it, use the quick-rising dry yeast. Add flavor. Mix in the olives, thyme, and salt, followed by a cup of flour. Mix it until the flour disappears. Add in the rest of the flour. Separating each cup, add in the flour cup by cup. Between additions, stir until the flour disappears. You can add more flour if the dough is too sticky. The dough should start pulling away from the sides of the bowl. Add the oil to a bowl, smoothing it up the sides. Dump the dough into it to cover it in oil. Place the dough in the fridge if you are making it ahead. If not, leave it to rise in a warm area of the room. When it's ready, the dough will be doubled. Heat the oven to 500 °F (260 °C). Let the oven preheat for 10 to 15 minutes. Rub a baking sheet with olive oil. Using your hands or a spoon, thoroughly coat a sheet with olive oil. The olive oil helps create a crispy crust on the bottom. Flour an area to work. Turn the dough out on the surface, making sure not to knead it. Cut it in half. Create baguettes. They should be 15 inches (38.1 cm) long and a couple of inches wide. Place them on the sheet. Let the dough rise again. In a warm area, leave the dough to rise for about 15 minutes (30 if using the dough from the refrigerator). Leave plastic wrap over it while it's rising. Top with egg white. Using a pastry brush, coat the top of each loaf with egg white. Humidify the oven. Water helps create a crusty loaf. Use a spray bottle to spray tap water into the oven, about 8 times. Start with 10 minutes. Begin baking the bread at 500 °F (260 °C) for 10 minutes. Lower the temperature to 400 °F (204 °C). Finish baking the bread for 35 minutes. Remove it to a cooling rack. Let it cool before serving.
